question: How might the restoration of SEVIS records while ICE crafts a new termination framework affect international students‚Äô due process and future immigration prospects?

content.source_1:
The Trump administration is restoring the legal status of international students who had their records terminated in recent weeks, a government attorney said Friday at a hearing.

Elizabeth D. Kurlan, an attorney for the Justice Department, said during the hearing in the Northern District of California in Oakland that records for international students will be reactivated for the time being, as Immigration and Customs Enforcement crafts a new policy that will ‚Äúprovide a framework for status record termination.‚Äù

The move comes weeks after the Trump administration began revoking the visas of some thousands of international students in addition to their records and legal statuses, seemingly taking aim at those who‚Äôve participated in political activism or have had previous charges, like DUIs.

‚ÄúICE still maintains the authority to terminate a SEVIS record for other reasons," Kurlan said at the hearing, referring to the Student and Exchange Visitor Program, "such as if a student fails to maintain his or her nonimmigrant status after the record is reactivated, or engages in other unlawful activity that would render him or her removable from the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act.‚Äù

Kurlan also said that going forward, ICE will not be terminating statuses solely based on findings in the National Crime Information Center, a computerized index that includes criminal history information, that resulted in some of the recent SEVIS record terminations.

Many international students with terminated statuses began to discover that their records were abruptly restored Thursday afternoon, immigration attorneys and universities across the U.S. told NBC News. The reinstatements occurred with little-to-no explanation, the attorneys said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like somebody flipped a light switch on,‚Äù Jath Shao, a Cleveland-based immigration attorney who has a client that experienced the sudden reversal.

The changes have hit many, but not all, students. At the University of California, Berkeley, a dozen of the 23 international students who had their records terminated in the SEVIS weeks ago were reinstated, university spokesperson Janet Gilmore said.

A few students at the Rochester Institute of Technology also experienced reinstatement, the school‚Äôs public information director, Carl Langsenkamp, said. Charles Kuck, an Atlanta-based attorney, said he has about a dozen clients who reported a similar reversal.

David Wilson, who represents around 20 students in Minnesota, said about half of his clients have had their statuses restored. He added, however, that there‚Äôs still a great deal of uncertainty, particularly because many of their student visas still remain revoked.

‚ÄúThat means they‚Äôre kind of trapped in the country. So that‚Äôll be the next phase of seeking clarity as to what the government‚Äôs actually doing,‚Äù Wilson said.

Additionally, the status termination will still appear on students‚Äô records, potentially jeopardizing any future applications for green cards or other relief, the immigration attorneys said.

‚ÄúThe time that they had their SEVIS status terminated could still have harmful effects for those students,‚Äù said Elora Mukherjee, director of the Immigrants‚Äô Rights Clinic at Columbia Law School. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs not enough for the federal government to simply restore service records. The government would need to somehow make the students whole.‚Äù

Shao, the attorney, said that the development is a small but positive one for international students. However, he said more needs to be done to guarantee their safety in the U.S.

‚ÄúBy now it‚Äôs obvious that the Trump administration spent the four years of Biden plotting their revenge on the immigration system,‚Äù Shao said. ‚ÄúBut once some brave students and lawyers went to the courts ‚Äî the administration‚Äôs defenders were unable or unwilling to explain the rationale.‚Äù

Chloe Atkins reports for the NBC News National Security and Law Unit, based in New York.

In a sudden reversal on Friday, the Trump administration announced it will reinstate thousands of foreign students to active status aftertheir records were terminatedfrom a database earlier this month.

TheDepartment of Justice(DOJ) announcedthe sweeping student visa reversalin federal court, following weeks of mounting legal pressure.

"While we are hearing about the reopening of some individual SEVIS records, the systemic harm caused by the original unlawful terminations continues‚Äîand our case should move forward," Miriam Feldblum, president and CEO of the Presidents' Alliance, which filed a lawsuit on the issue Thursday, said in a statement toNewsweek.

"Reactivating a record does not erase questions about the genesis of this unlawful policy. It also does not remove the original termination notation or the stated reason from SEVIS records, both of which can have long-term negative consequences for students. Nor does it prevent the Trump administration from reversing conduct and returning to these unlawful behaviors."

TheDepartment of Homeland Security(DHS) later said it had not reversed course on student visa revocations, but instead the active status of those visa holders.

Newsweekreached out to the DOJ for comment via email Friday morning.

Around 5,000 students are estimated to have had their visas revoked or legal status deleted by the administration in recent weeks, putting them at risk of deportation. Around 100 lawsuits were filed, challenging the move.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Joseph Carilli told a federal court in Washington, D.C., that Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) was developing a framework for SEVIS record terminations, but that, for now, all plaintiffs in the case and other affected students would see their status restored.

SEVIS stands for the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System. It's a web-based system which DHS uses to track the immigration status of foreign students while in the U.S., often in the country on F-1 visas.

The sweeping revocation of these visas began nearly two months ago. First, with high-profile cases, such asRumeysa Ozturk in Massachusettsbefore morereports started appearing of other revocations.

Hundreds of students then sued in various courts across the country, with many of them never having been charged or convicted of a crime or having only faced minor offenses, such as a speeding ticket.

Carilli said Friday that while status was being restored, ICE maintains the authority to terminate the status of those who do not maintain their immigrant status or break any laws.

The sweeping reversal comes after a judge in Georgia ordered the restoration of 133 visas last week.

In a separate case Friday, U.S. District JudgeTanya Chutkanordered an Ohio State University student's visa be restored.

Graduate Ahwar Sultan was arrested at a pro-Palestinian rally, which led officials to revoke his visa two weeks ago. Chutkan said this was not grounds for visa revocation.

Sultan, who was arrested in April 2024, later saw the charges associated with his arrest dismissed and expunged.

The judge's ruling came around the same time as the nationwide turnaround.

Miriam Feldblum, president and CEO of the Presidents' Alliance, in her statement toNewsweek: "Our case seeks a complete end to the unlawful policy, not just piecemeal fixes. This is why systemic litigation like ours remains crucial‚Äîto ensure full relief, prevent future harm, and safeguard students' ability to remain in and return to the United States without risk."

DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin in a statement toNewsweek: "We have not reversed course on a single visa revocation. What we did is restore SEVIS access for people who had not had their visa revoked."

Charles Kuck, an immigration attorney with Kuck Baxter in Atlanta, toldNewsweek: "It is good to see ICE recognize the illegality of its actions canceling SEVIS registrations for these students. Sad that it took losing 50 times. What we don't yet know is what ICE will do to repair the damage it has done, especially for those students who lost jobs and offers and had visas revoked. We await their answer."

Assistant U.S. Attorney Joseph Carilli reading a written statement Friday:"ICE is developing a policy that will provide a framework for SEVIS record terminations. Until such a policy is issued, the SEVIS records for plaintiff(s) in this case (and other similarly situated plaintiffs) will remain active or shall be reactivated if not currently active, and ICE will not modify the record solely based on the NCIC finding that resulted in the recent SEVIS record termination."

Carilli said Friday that similar statements will be filed in the other student visa cases across the country.

The Department of Justice announced the decision in federal court

The Trump administration on Friday restored thousands of visa registrations for foreign students who had either a minor or dismissed legal infraction.

The Justice Department announced the decision in federal court,according to the news outlet Politico.

The administration last month abruptly decided to remove foreign students from a federal database used by universities to track foreign students.

Students were concerned they lost their immigration status and could be deported.

Several judges ruled against the administration and said removing the students from the database was illegal. Over 100 lawsuits were launched as a result of the decision.
